ai-mn16:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-mn16:2.1_0: “Mendicants, when a mendicant has not given up five kinds of emotional barrenness and cut off five emotional shackles, it’s not possible for them to achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.
ai-mn16:3.1_0: What are the five kinds of emotional barrenness they haven’t given up?
ai-mn16:3.2_0: Firstly, a mendicant has doubts about the Teacher. They’re not uncertain, undecided, or lacking confidence.
ai-mn16:3.3_0: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
ai-mn16:3.4_0: This is the first kind of emotional barrenness.
ai-mn16:4.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant has doubts about the teaching ...
ai-mn16:4.2_0: This is the second kind of emotional barrenness.
ai-mn16:5.1_0: They have doubts about the Saṅgha ...
ai-mn16:5.2_0: This is the third kind of emotional barrenness.
ai-mn16:6.1_0: They have doubts about the training ...
ai-mn16:6.2_0: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
ai-mn16:6.3_0: This is the fourth kind of emotional barrenness.
ai-mn16:7.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is angry and upset with their spiritual companions, resentful and closed off.
ai-mn16:7.2_0: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
ai-mn16:7.3_0: This is the fifth kind of emotional barrenness.
ai-mn16:7.4_0: These are the five kinds of emotional barrenness they haven’t given up.
ai-mn16:8.1_0: What are the five emotional shackles they haven’t cut off?
ai-mn16:8.2_0: Firstly, a mendicant isn’t free of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.
ai-mn16:8.3_0: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
ai-mn16:8.4_0: This is the first emotional shackle.
ai-mn16:9.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t free of greed for the body ...
ai-mn16:9.2_0: This is the second emotional shackle.
ai-mn16:10.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t free of greed for form ...
ai-mn16:10.2_0: This is the third emotional shackle.
ai-mn16:11.1_0: They eat as much as they like until their belly is full, then indulge in the pleasures of sleeping, lying down, and drowsing ...
ai-mn16:11.2_0: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
ai-mn16:11.3_0: This is the fourth emotional shackle.
ai-mn16:12.1_0: They lead the spiritual life hoping to be reborn in one of the orders of gods, thinking:
ai-mn16:12.1_1: ‘By this precept by this precept or observance or mortification or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’
ai-mn16:12.2_0: Any mendicant who leads the spiritual life hoping to be reborn in one of the orders of gods:
ai-mn16:12.2_1: ‘By this precepts or observances, I will incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.’
ai-mn16:12.3_0: This is the fifth emotional shackle.
ai-mn16:12.4_0: These are the five emotional shackles they haven’t cut off.
ai-mn16:13.1_0: When a mendicant has not given up these five kinds of emotional barrenness and cut off these five emotional shackles, it’s not possible for them to achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.
ai-mn16:14.1_0: When a mendicant has given up these five kinds of emotional barrenness and cut off these five emotional shackles, it is possible for them to achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.
ai-mn16:15.1_0: What are the five kinds of emotional barrenness they’ve given up?
ai-mn16:15.2_0: Firstly, a mendicant has no doubts about the Teacher. They’re not uncertain, undecided, or lacking confidence.
ai-mn16:15.3_0: This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
ai-mn16:15.4_0: This is the first kind of emotional barrenness.
ai-mn16:16.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant has no doubts about the teaching ...
ai-mn16:16.2_0: This is the second kind of emotional barrenness.
ai-mn16:17.1_0: They have no doubts about the Saṅgha ...
ai-mn16:17.2_0: This is the third kind of emotional barrenness.
ai-mn16:18.1_0: They have no doubts about the training ...
ai-mn16:18.2_0: This is the fourth kind of emotional barrenness.
ai-mn16:19.1_0: They’re not angry and upset with their spiritual companions, not resentful or closed off.
ai-mn16:19.2_0: This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
ai-mn16:19.3_0: This is the fifth kind of emotional barrenness.
ai-mn16:19.4_0: These are the five kinds of emotional barrenness they’ve given up.
ai-mn16:20.1_0: What are the five emotional shackles they’ve cut off?
ai-mn16:20.2_0: Firstly, a mendicant is rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.
ai-mn16:20.3_0: This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
ai-mn16:20.4_0: This is the first emotional shackle.
ai-mn16:21.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t free of greed for the body ...
ai-mn16:22.1_0: They’re free of greed for form ...
ai-mn16:23.1_0: They don’t eat as much as they like until their belly is full, then indulge in the pleasures of sleeping, lying down, and drowsing ...
ai-mn16:23.2_0: This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
ai-mn16:23.3_0: This is the fourth emotional shackle.
ai-mn16:24.1_0: They don’t lead the spiritual life hoping to be reborn in one of the orders of gods, thinking:
ai-mn16:24.1_1: ‘By this precept by this precept or observance or mortification or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’
ai-mn16:24.2_0: This being so, the spiritual life,
ai-mn16:24.2_1: ‘By this precepts or observances, I will incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.’
ai-mn16:24.3_0: This is the fifth emotional shackle.
ai-mn16:24.4_0: These are the five emotional shackles they’ve cut off.
ai-mn16:25.1_0: When a mendicant has given up these five kinds of emotional barrenness and cut off these five emotional shackles, it is possible for them to achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.
ai-mn16:26.1_0: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort ...
ai-mn16:26.2_0: the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy, and active effort ...
ai-mn16:26.3_0: the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to mental development, and active effort ...
ai-mn16:26.4_0: the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to inquiry, and active effort. And the fifth is sheer vigor.
ai-mn16:27.1_0: A mendicant who possesses these fifteen factors, including vigor, is capable of breaking out, becoming awakened, and reaching the supreme sanctuary.
ai-mn16:27.2_0: Suppose, suppose there were a hen with eight or ten or twelve eggs,
ai-mn16:27.3_0: which she had properly covered, properly warmed, and properly incubated.
ai-mn16:27.5_0: ‘If only my chicks could break out of the eggshell with their claws and beak and hatch safely!’
ai-mn16:27.6_0: But still they can break out and hatch safely.
ai-mn16:27.7_0: In the same way, a mendicant who possesses these fifteen factors, including vigor, is capable of breaking out, becoming awakened, and reaching the supreme sanctuary.”
ai-mn16:27.8_0: This is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn16:27.9_0: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-mn16:27.10_0: The sixth section on the emotional barrenness is finished.
